meanings.definition: To adapt (a story or event) into a dramatic form.
meanings.sent1: She decided to dramatise the book by turning it into a play for her friends.
meanings.sent2: The director chose to dramatise the historical event to engage the audience.
meanings.sent3: The children dramatised their favorite fairy tale during the school play.
meanings.sent4: Her storytelling skills could dramatise even the simplest of anecdotes.
meanings.sent5: The artist's brushstrokes seemed to dramatise the scene on the canvas.

meanings.definition: To make (something) seem more exciting or important than it really is.
meanings.sent1: The reality TV show producers often dramatise the contestants' reactions for entertainment.
meanings.sent2: Some news outlets tend to dramatise minor incidents to attract more viewers.
meanings.sent3: His exaggerated gestures always dramatise his storytelling, making everyone laugh.
meanings.sent4: The politician's speech aimed to dramatise the urgency of the situation.
meanings.sent5: The magician's tricks were designed to dramatise the magic of the performance.
